case_name: Partnership firm carrying business in bamboos, timber and firewood at Gokavaram v. Commercial Tax Officer, Rajahmundry

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2176 of 1966 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2176 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 16, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 1404 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 16, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 1404 of 1963.

facts.text: The appellant is a partnership firm carrying business in bamboos, timber and firewood at Gokavaram in the State of Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a partnership firm carrying business in bamboos, timber and firewood at Gokavaram in the State of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: The firm had been registered as a dealer under the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act No. VI of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The firm had been registered as a dealer under the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act  No. VI of 1957 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1962-63, the appellant submitted a return showing a gross turnover of Rs. 13,89,130.70 P.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1962-63, the appellant submitted a return showing a gross turnover of Rs. 13,89,130.70 P and claimed exemption...

facts.text: Appellant claimed exemption on a turnover of Rs. 13,68,174.39 P which represented sales effected by its commission agents and sales of firewood.

anchor.surface_text: and claimed exemption on a turnover of Rs. 13,68,174.39 P which according to the appellant represented the amount of sales effected by its companymission agents and sales of firewood.

facts.text: By a notice dated November 28, 1963, the Commercial Tax Officer, Rajahmundry called upon the appellant to show cause as to why it should be assessed for the year 1962-63 on a turnover of Rs. 13,89,130.70 P at 2 per cent.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberice dated November 28, 1963, the Commercial Tax Officer, Rajahmundry called upon the appellant to show cause as to why it should number be assessed for the year 1962-63 on a turnover of Rs. 13,89,130.70 P at 2 per cent.

facts.text: Item No 1 in the notice related to a turnover of Rs. 96,527.10 P under the firewood account.

anchor.surface_text: Eleven items were companyprised in the numberice. Item No 1, relating to a turnover of Rs. 96,527.10 P was under the firewood account.

facts.text: Appellant alleged that it paid the single point tax at 2 per cent to the Forest Department on the amounts for which the forest goods were taken in auction.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged by the appellant that it paid the single point tax at 2 per cent to the Forest Department on the amounts for which the forest goods were taken in auction.

facts.text: As regards items 2 to 11 the appellant claimed exemption on the ground that its agents paid the tax.

anchor.surface_text: As regards items 2 to 11 the appellant claimed exemption on the ground that its agents, Messrs. Kusuma Arjayya and Batlanki Veera Venkayya, Rajahmundry, paid the tax.

facts.text: Appellant's agents were Messrs. Kusuma Arjayya and Batlanki Veera Venkayya, Rajahmundry.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant was that L1 Sup. C.I./68-16 it sent goods for sale to its companymission agents and under the companytract of agency the companymission agents were empowered to pay sales-tax and had paid the same directly to the Sales Tax Department.

facts.text: Appellant sent goods for sale to its commission agents.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the usual companymercial practice the companymission agents companylected Dharmam on the sales companyducted by them and appropriated those companylections for charitable purposes.

facts.text: Under the contract of agency the commission agents were empowered to pay sales-tax and had paid the same directly to the Sales Tax Department.

anchor.surface_text: the companymission agents were empowered to pay sales-tax and had paid the same directly to the Sales Tax Department. In accordance with the usual companymercial practice the companymission agents companylected Dharmam on the sales companyducted by them

facts.text: Commission agents collected Dharmam on the sales conducted by them and appropriated those collections for charitable purposes.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the usual companymercial practice the companymission agents companylected Dharmam on the sales companyducted by them and appropriated those companylections for charitable purposes.

facts.text: Commission agents furnished accounts to the appellant but sales-tax and Dharmam amounts were not specifically shown as understood to be remitted.

anchor.surface_text: The companymission agents furnished accounts to the appellant but in these accounts the amounts companylected towards sales-tax and Dharmam were number specifically shown as it was understood between the parties that the amounts companylected towards sales tax would be remitted to the Sales Tax Department

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition No. 1404 of 1963 dated December 7, 1963 before the High Court of Andhra Pradesh under Art. 226 praying for certiorari to quash the notice dated November 28, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the assessment numberice of the respondent disallowing its claim for exemption the appellant-firm filed a writ petition No. 1404 of 1963 dated December 7, 1963 before the High Court of Andhra Pradesh under Art. 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: High Court by judgment dated April 16, 1964 dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated April 16, 1964 the High Court dismissed the writ petition. This appeal is brought by a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Appeal brought by certificate granted by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought by a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed we hold that the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh is right and this appeal must be dismissed.

facts.text: Eleven items were comprised in the notice.

anchor.surface_text: Eleven items were companyprised in the numberice.

facts.text: Court held that the real object of the Explanation is to prevent misuse by assessee of principal-agent relationship for evading tax.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the real object of the Explanation is to prevent the misuse by the assessee of the relationship of principal and agent for the purpose of evading tax.

anchor.surface_text: the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act  No. VI of 1957 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

concepts.unlisted_label: Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act, 1957
concepts.unlisted_description: State legislation imposing sales tax on dealers

anchor.surface_text: Explanation III to s. 2  1    n  of the Act defines sale as follows sale with all its grammatical variations and cognate expressions means every transfer of the property in goods by one person to another in the course of trade or business, for cash, or for deferred payment, or for any other valuable consideration,  and includes any transfer of materials for money consideration in the execution of a works contract provided that the contract for the transfer of such materials can be separated from the contract for the services and the work done, although the two contracts are embodied in a single document  or in the supply or distribution of goods by a society  including a co-operative society , club, firm or associations to its members, but does not include a mortgage hypothecation or pledge of, or a charge on goods NOTE -By Amendment Act 26, 1961, the brac- keted words were substituted for the words and includes a transfer of property in goods involved in the execution of a works contract.

concepts.interpretation: Defines 'sale' including transfers in course of business; Explanation III deems two sales in principal-agent scenarios where agent does not fully account

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: g agent to the purchaser, or  2  when the goods are transferred from the seller to a buying agent and from the buying agent to his principal, if the a

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 2(n), Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act, 1957
concepts.unlisted_description: Definition of 'sale' for sales tax purposes

anchor.surface_text: Explanation III -Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act or in the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930  Central Act III of 1930 , two independent sales or purchases shall, for the purposes of this Act, be deemed to have taken place-  1  when the goods are transferred from a principal to his selling agent and from the selling agent to the purchaser, or  2  when the goods are transferred from the seller to a buying agent and from the buying agent to his principal, if the agent is found in either of the cases aforesaid- to have sold the goods at one rate and to have passed on the sale proceeds to his principal at another rate or to have purchased the goods at one rate and to have passed them on to his principal at another rate or not to have accounted to his principal for the entire collections or deductions made by him, in the sales or purchases effected by him on behalf of his principal or to have acted for a fictitious or non- existent principal

concepts.interpretation: Prevents tax evasion by deeming two sales where agent misuses relationship, but only applies when title transfers, not mere agency

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out by this Court in The State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd. that the expression sale of goods in Entry 48 in List II of Sch. VII of the Government of India Act, 1935, cannot be construed in its popular sense but must be interpreted in its legal sense and should be given the same meaning which it has in the Sale of Goods Act, 1930. It is res inter alios acta, its essential ingredients being an agreement to sell movables for a price and property passing therein pursuant to that agreement.

concepts.interpretation: Agreement to transfer title for price; Explanation consistent as it applies only to actual title transfers

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ade by him, in the sales or purchases effected by him on behalf of his principal or to have acted for a fictitious or number- existent principal In ou

concepts.unlisted_description: Legal meaning requiring transfer of title for consideration

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of law there is a distinction between a contract of sale and a contract of agency by which the agent is authorised to sell or buy on behalf of the principal and make over either the sale proceeds or the goods to the principal. The essence of a contract of sale is the transfer of title to the goods for a price paid or promised to be paid. The transferee in such a case is liable to the transferor as a debtor for the price to be paid and not as agent for the proceeds of the sale. The essence of agency to sell is the delivery of the goods to a person who is to sell them, not as his own property but as the property of the principal who continues to be the owner of the goods and will therefore be liable to account for the sale proceeds.

concepts.interpretation: Determined from contract terms, conditions; terminology not decisive; requires factual investigation

issues.text: Whether Explanation III to Section 2(n) of the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act, 1957 enlarges the scope of the word 'sale' by means of a legal fiction converting transactions that are not sales into taxable sales, and is therefore ultra vires the powers of the State Legislature under Entry 48, List II, Seventh Schedule to the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was contended, in the first place, that Explanation III to s. 2 1 n of the Act enlarged the scope of the word sale and by means of a fiction converted what are not sales in law into taxable sales for the purpose of the Act and, therefore, the Explanation was ultra, vires of the powers of the State Legislature which had not legislative competence to impose a tax under Entry 48 in List II of Sch. VII of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the transactions relating to items Nos. 2 to 11 in the assessment notice constitute contracts of sale (attracting Explanation III and liability on the appellant) or mere contracts of agency (where agents had already paid sales tax, exempting the appellant from further tax)?

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the appellant that in any event items Nos. 2 to II of the notice related to goods which the appellant had sent for sale to the commission agents and as the latter had already paid the sales-tax the appellant was not liable to be assessed to tax again on the same transaction as there was only one sale. As a matter of law there is a distinction between a contract of sale and a contract of agency by which the agent is authorised to sell or buy on behalf of the principal

issues.text: Whether Explanation III to Section 2(n) of the Act violates Article 14 of the Constitution on grounds of unreasonable classification between commission agents who fully account for collections and those who do not?

anchor.surface_text: It was also submitted on behalf of the appellant that the third Explanation to s. 2 1 n of the Act violated the guarantee under Art. 14 of the Constitution since the classification contemplated, i.e., sales through commission agents who account fully for all collection made and sales through commission agents who do not account for collections, was not made on any intelligible differentia and had no rational relationship to the purpose of the statute.

arguments.claim: Explanation III to s. 2(n) of the Act enlarged the scope of the word 'sale' by means of a fiction converting what are not sales in law into taxable sales, making it ultra vires the powers of the State Legislature under Entry 48 List II Sch. VII

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was contended, in the first place, that Explanation III to s. 2  1    n  of the Act enlarged the scope of the word sale and by means of a fiction converted what are not sales in law into taxable sales for the purpose of the Act and, therefore, the Explanation was ultra, vires of the powers of the State Legislature which had not legislative competence to impose a tax under Entry 48 in List II of Sch. VII of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Explanation only deems two sales where title actually transfers from principal to agent and agent to buyer, consistent with legal definition of sale; prevents tax evasion without enlarging scope

arguments.claim: Transactions in items 2 to 11 are contracts of agency where commission agents paid sales tax directly, so appellant not liable for tax on same turnover as only one sale

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the appellant that in any event items Nos. 2 to II of the notice related to goods which the appellant had sent for sale to the commission agents and as the latter had already paid the sales-tax the appellant was not liable to be assessed to tax again on the same transaction as there was only one sale.

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinction between sale (title transfer) and agency (no title transfer, agent accounts); mixed question of fact/law requiring investigation by taxing authority, not writ court under Art. 226

arguments.claim: Explanation III violates Art. 14 due to unreasonable classification between sales through agents who fully account and those who do not, lacking intelligible differentia and rational nexus

anchor.surface_text: It was also submitted on behalf of the appellant that the third Explanation to s. 2 1   n  of the Act violated the guarantee under Art. 14 of the Constitution since the classification contemplated, i.e., sales through commission agents who account fully for all collection made and sales through commission agents who do not account for collections, was not made on any intelligible differentia and had no rational relationship to the purpose of the statute.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s a rational relationship with the object sought to be achieved by the statute. Counsel for the appellant is therefore unable to make good his submiss

arguments.court_reasoning: Classification based on intelligible differentia (full accounting vs not) with rational relation to preventing tax evasion

arguments.claim: Real object of Explanation III is to prevent misuse of principal-agent relationship for tax evasion

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the real object of the Explanation is to prevent the misuse by the assessee of the relationship of principal and agent for the purpose of evading tax.

arguments.claim: Explanation III imposes tax only on actual transfers of title, deeming two sales where principal transfers to agent and agent to buyer

anchor.surface_text: The real effect of the third Explanation is to impose the tax only when there was a transfer of title to the goods and not where there is a mere contract of agency. The Explanation says in effect that where there is in reality a transfer of property by the principal to the agent and by the agent in his turn to the buyer, there are two transactions of sale.

arguments.claim: 'Sale of goods' in Entry 48 must have legal meaning from Sale of Goods Act: agreement to transfer title for price

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out by this Court in The State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd. that the expression sale of goods in Entry 48 in List II of Sch. VII of the Government of India Act, 1935, cannot be construed in its popular sense but must be interpreted in its legal sense and should be given the same meaning which it has in the Sale of Goods Act, 1930.

arguments.claim: Essence of sale is transfer of title for price; agency is delivery without title transfer, agent accounts for proceeds

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of law there is a distinction between a contract of sale and a contract of agency by which the agent is authorised to sell or buy on behalf of the principal and make over either the sale proceeds or the goods to the principal. The essence of a contract of sale is the transfer of title to the goods for a price paid or promised to be paid.

arguments.claim: Relationship determined by contract terms/conditions, not terminology; analogies to Lamb v Goring and Hutton v Lippert

anchor.surface_text: The true relationship of the parties in each case has to be gathered from the nature of the contract, its terms and conditions, and the terminology used by the parties is not decisive of the legal relationship. For instance, in W. T. Lamb and Sons v. Goring Brick Company Limited there was an agreement...

arguments.claim: Whether transactions are sales or agency is mixed question of fact/law for taxing authority, not writ under Art. 226

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the question as to whether the transactions in the present case are sales or contracts of agency is a mixed question of fact and law and must be investigated with reference to the material which the appellant might be able to place before the appropriate authority. The question is not one which can properly be determined in an application for a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Appellant paid single point tax at 2% to Forest Department on firewood auction amounts, exempt from further tax

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged by the appellant that it paid the single point tax at 2 per cent to the Forest Department on the amounts for which the forest goods were taken in auction.

holdings.text: The real object of Explanation III to s. 2(n) is to prevent the misuse by the assessee of the relationship of principal and agent for the purpose of evading tax.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the real object of the Explanation is to prevent the misuse by the assessee of the relationship of principal and agent for the purpose of evading tax. The first situation contemplated by the legislature is that covered by cl. (i) of Explanation III where the agent has sold the goods at one rate and passed on the sale proceeds to its principal at another rate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation identifies legislative intent to curb tax evasion through four specified situations of agent misconduct.

holdings.text: There is no warrant for the argument that the State legislature was not competent to convert by a legal fiction a mere entrustment of goods for sale into a sale; the Explanation imposes tax only on transfer of title, not mere agency.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no warrant for this argument. The real effect of the third Explanation is to impose the tax only when there was a transfer of title to the goods and not where there is a mere contract of agency. The Explanation says in effect that where there is in reality a transfer of property by the principal to the agent and by the agent in his turn to the buyer, there are two transactions of sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction limits deeming to actual title transfers, consistent with legal definition of sale from Sale of Goods Act as per Gannon Dunkerley precedent.

holdings.text: The phrase 'when the goods are transferred' in clauses (1) and (2) of Explanation III means when title to the goods is transferred, so the Explanation does not enlarge the scope of the main section.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the phrase when the goods are transferred in cls. (1) and (2) of Explanation III on a proper construction means when title to the goods is transferred and so construed it is impossible to say that the Explanation enlarges the scope of the main section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proper construction aligns with legal sense of 'sale' requiring title passage, preventing ultra vires expansion.

holdings.text: It is impossible to accept that the Explanation has converted what is not a sale into a sale for sales-tax assessment purposes.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore impossible to accept the contention put forward on behalf of the appellant that the Explanation has converted what, in fact, is not a sale into a sale for the purpose of assessment to sales-tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation applies solely to genuine title transfers, upholding legislative competence under Entry 48 List II.

holdings.text: There is a distinction between a contract of sale (transfer of title for price) and a contract of agency (delivery without title transfer, agent accounts for proceeds).

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of law there is a distinction between a contract of sale and a contract of agency by which the agent is authorised to sell or buy on behalf of the principal and make over either the sale proceeds or the goods to the principal. The essence of a contract of sale is the transfer of title to the goods for a price paid or promised to be paid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defines essences based on title passage versus ownership retention and accounting obligation.

holdings.text: The true relationship between parties is gathered from the nature of the contract, its terms and conditions; terminology used by parties is not decisive.

anchor.surface_text: The true relationship of the parties in each case has to be gathered from the nature of the contract, its terms and conditions, and the terminology used by the parties is not decisive of the legal relationship. For instance, in W. T. Lamb and Sons v. Goring Brick Company Limited there was an agreement...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to precedents Lamb v Goring and Hutton v Lippert where labels did not control substance.

holdings.text: Whether the transactions are sales or contracts of agency is a mixed question of fact and law to be investigated by the appropriate authority, not properly determinable in a writ petition under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the question as to whether the transactions in the present case are sales or contracts of agency is a mixed question of fact and law and must be investigated with reference to the material which the appellant might be able to place before the appropriate authority. The question is not one which can properly be determined in an application for a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdictional limit of writ court precludes fact-intensive inquiry; remit to taxing authority.

holdings.text: Explanation III does not violate Art. 14 as the classification (agents who fully account vs those who do not) is based on intelligible differentia with rational relationship to the statutory object.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no substance in this argument as the classification is based upon an intelligible differentia and it has a rational relationship with the object sought to be achieved by the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies reasonable classification test: differentia (full accounting) rationally advances anti-evasion purpose.

holdings.text: The judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh is right and this appeal must be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed we hold that the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh is right and this appeal must be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings uphold lower court dismissal of writ against assessment notice.

precedents.citation: The State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. Madras Ltd.1

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. Madras Ltd.1

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: the expression sale of goods in Entry 48 in List II of Sch. VII of the Government of India Act, 1935, cannot be construed in its popular sense but must be interpreted in its legal sense and should be given the same meaning which it has in the Sale of Goods Act, 1930
precedents.cited_holding: It is a rule of law, its essential ingredients being an agreement to sell movables for a price and property passing therein pursuant to that agreement. In other words, it is necessary for constituting a sale that there should be an agreement between the parties for the purpose of transferring title in the goods, that the agreement must be supported by money consideration and that as a result of the transaction the title to the property must actually pass in the goods.

precedents.cited_holding: the agreement was one of vendor and purchaser and not one of principal and agent

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the real object of the Explanation is to prevent the misuse by the assessee of the relationship of principal and agent for the purpose of evading tax. The first situation contemplated by the legislature is that covered by cl. (i) of Explanation III where the agent has sold the goods at one rate and passed on the sale proceeds to its principal at another rate.
For the reasons expressed we hold that the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh is right and this appeal must be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no warrant for this argument. The real effect of the third Explanation is to impose the tax only when there was a transfer of title to the goods and not where there is a mere contract of agency. The Explanation says in effect that where there is in reality a transfer of property by the principal to the agent and by the agent in his turn to the buyer, there are two transactions of sale.
For the reasons expressed we hold that the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh is right and this appeal must be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of law there is a distinction between a contract of sale and a contract of agency by which the agent is authorised to sell or buy on behalf of the principal and make over either the sale proceeds or the goods to the principal. The essence of a contract of sale is the transfer of title to the goods for a price paid or promised to be paid.
For the reasons expressed we hold that the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh is right and this appeal must be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the question as to whether the transactions in the present case are sales or contracts of agency is a mixed question of fact and law and must be investigated with reference to the material which the appellant might be able to place before the appropriate authority. The question is not one which can properly be determined in an application for a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.
For the reasons expressed we hold that the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh is right and this appeal must be dismissed.
